New Records: The Dodgers bullpen combined for seven strikeouts while scattering seven hits, marking a significant defensive performance.
Key Match Events: The Dodgers' bullpen stymied the Padres one after the other, with eight relievers combining for seven strikeouts and no Padres runner advancing beyond second base.
Gavin Lux's seventh-inning homer expanded the lead to eight.
Daniel Hudson disarmed Fernando Tatis Jr. with five consecutive sweeps.
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers pitching coach, Mark Prior, and the team's brain trust spent nine hours preparing for the game, poring over spreadsheets and heat maps to create a blueprint for 27 outs without a starting pitcher.
Manager Dave Roberts suggested the Dodgers would be 'throwing a bunch of arms at these guys today, giving them different looks.'
Post-Match Reflections: Manager Dave Roberts expressed excitement about Game 5, citing the team's resilience and desire.
Reliever Daniel Hudson praised the chemistry in the clubhouse and the grit of the team.
Pitching coach Mark Prior credited the players for their performance, saying 'every one of them did their job.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers' bullpen survived its own slew of injuries and finished the season with the fourth-lowest ERA in baseball.
The midseason acquisition of Michael Kopech provided the team with another option for a late-game group.
The Padres have hammered Dodgers starters throughout the series, but the bullpen kept them at bay on Wednesday.
Others: The Dodgers will face Yu Darvish in Game 5, with Game 1 starter Yoshinobu Yamamoto available on six days of rest.
The team could potentially execute another bullpen game in Game 5.
